qas.question: What did the Swingle Singers primarily use to emulate musical instruments?
What is another term for beatboxing?
What was used to make an a capella recording of The Who Sell Out?
What car manufacturer hired Petra Haden to perform a capella songs in commercials for their car?
On what website can many a capella groups' music be listened to?
What did the Beach Boys use so they would sound like instruments?
What added new dimensions to nonsense words?
What is one song version The Swingle Singers released in 2005?
What did Toyota hire The Bellamy Brothers to advertise in their commercials?
What was used by Journey to make an a cappella recording of The Who Sells Out?

context: The Swingle Singers used <a0_0><b5_0>nonsense words<b5_0/><a0_0/> to sound like instruments, but have been known to produce non-verbal versions of musical instruments. Like the other groups, examples of their music can be found on <a4_0>YouTube<a4_0/>. Beatboxing, more accurately known as <a1_0>vocal percussion<a1_0/>, is a technique used in a cappella music popularized by the hip-hop community, where rap is often performed a cappella also. The advent of <b6_0>vocal percussion<b6_0/> added new dimensions to the a cappella genre and has become very prevalent in modern arrangements. Petra Haden used <a2_0><b9_0>a four-track recorder<b9_0/><a2_0/> to produce an a cappella version of The Who Sell Out including the instruments and fake advertisements on her album Petra Haden Sings: The Who Sell Out in 2005. Haden has also released a cappella versions of Journey's "Don't Stop Believin'", The Beach Boys' "God Only Knows" and <b7_0>Michael Jackson's "Thriller"<b7_0/>. In 2009, <a3_0>Toyota<a3_0/> commissioned Haden to perform three songs for television commercials for <b8_0>the third-generation Toyota Prius<b8_0/>, including an a cappella version of The Bellamy Brothers' 1970s song "Let Your Love Flow".[citation needed]
